title: Deven Misra
text:
I am a graduate student at The University of Tokyo and a member of the Belle II group at the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe. My advisor is Professor  Takeo Higuchi.
Previously, I was a research assistant at Reed College, where I worked with Professor Noah Charles on disordered network models for the integer quantum hall transition. Before that, I was a SULI intern in the Data Science and Machine Intelligence group at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, where my mentor was Dr. Jan Strube.
I earned my B.A. in Physics from Reed College in May 2022. My thesis advisor was Professor Joel Franklin.

title: Research
text:
I am currently a member of the Belle II collaboration affiliated with the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe. My research focuses on developing fast machine learning algorithms on FPGAs for the Belle II L1 trigger.




Before joining Belle II, I worked on the development and implementation of advanced machine learning algorithms for energy and angle reconstruction in the Zero-Degree Calorimeter for the future Electron-Ion Collider. Data from simulations was used to perform the first angle reconstruction for hadronic showers in the far-forward calorimetry using a graph neural network. I also worked with the ePIC collaboration on refinement and validation of a new DD4hep-based framework for simulation studies.

title: Deven Misra
text:
From October 2024, I will be a graduate student (M1) in the Belle II group at the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe. My advisor is Professor  Takeo Higuchi.
Since October 2023, I have been a research assistant at Reed College supervised by Professor Noah Charles. Before that, I was a SULI intern in the Data Science and Machine Intelligence group at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, where my mentor was Dr. Jan Strube. I earned my B.A. in Physics from Reed College in May 2022. My thesis advisor was Professor Joel Franklin.
In 2019, I was a visiting researcher at the Johns Hopkins University Robot and Protein Kinematics Laboratory supervised by Professor Gregory Chirikjian.

title: Deven Misra
text:
From October 2024, I will be a graduate student (M1) in the Belle II group at the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe. My advisor is Professor  Takeo Higuchi.
Since October 2023, I have been a research assistant at Reed College supervised by Professor Noah Charles. title: Research
text: I am currently a member of the Belle II collaboration affiliated with the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe in association with the Institute of Particle and Nuclear Studies. My research focuses on developing fast machine learning algorithms on FPGAs for the Belle II L1 trigger.

title: Research
text: Integer Quantum Hall Effect

title: Research
text:
Integer Quantum Hall Transitions
I am currently working on analytic and computational methods for introducing geometric disorder to the Chalker-Coddington network model.

Related Publications

D. Misra, O. Lee, H. Saberhagen, D. Schroeter and N. Charles, “Geometrically Disordered Network Models for the Integer Quantum Hall Transition via Loop Diagram Insertions,” 2024 APS March Meeting, Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA, 2024.

title: Research
text: I am a member of the Belle II collaboration affiliated with the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe. My current research focuses on the development and implementation of fast machine learning algorithms on FPGA architectures to improve the performance of the Belle II L1 trigger.

Related Publications

title: Research
text:
Quantum Hall Transitions
I am currently working on introducing geometric disorder to the Chalker-Coddington network model in order to accurately compute the critical exponent for the integer quantum hall transition.

Related Publications

D. Misra, O. Lee, H. Saberhagen, D. Schroeter and N. Charles, “Geometrically Disordered Network Models for the Integer Quantum Hall Transition via Loop Diagram Insertions,” 2024 APS March Meeting, Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA, 2024.

title: Research
section: Phase Transitions in the Quantum Hall Effect
text:
Phase Transitions in the Quantum Hall Effect
I am currently working on introducing geometric disorder to the Chalker-Coddington network model in order to accurately compute the critical exponent for the integer quantum hall transition.

Related Publications

D. Misra, O. Lee, H. Saberhagen, D. Schroeter and N. Charles, “Geometrically Disordered Network Models for the Integer Quantum Hall Transition via Loop Diagram Insertions,” 2024 APS March Meeting, Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA, 2024.

title: Research
text:
Quantum Phase Transitions
I am currently working on a novel method of introducing geometric disorder to the Chalker-Coddington network model in order to accurately compute the critical exponent for the integer quantum hall transition.

Related Publications

D. Misra, O. Lee, H. Saberhagen, D. Schroeter and N. Charles, “Geometrically Disordered Network Models for the Integer Quantum Hall Transition via Loop Diagram Insertions,” 2024 APS March Meeting, Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA, 2024.

title: Research
text: I am a member of the Belle II collaboration affiliated with the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe (IPMU). My current research focuses on the development and implementation of fast machine learning algorithms on FPGA architectures to improve the performance of the Belle II L1 trigger.

text:

I am currently working with Professor Noah Charles on a novel method of introducing geometric disorder to the Chalker-Coddington network model in order to accurately compute the critical exponent for the integer quantum hall transition.

title: Research
text:
I am currently a member of the Belle II collaboration affiliated with the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe. My research focuses on developing fast machine learning algorithms on FPGAs for the Belle II L1 trigger.




Before joining Belle II, I worked on the development and implementation of advanced machine learning algorithms for energy and angle reconstruction in the Zero-Degree Calorimeter for the future Electron-Ion Collider. Data from simulations was used to perform the first angle reconstruction for hadronic showers in the far-forward calorimetry using a graph neural network. I also worked with the ePIC collaboration on refinement and validation of a new DD4hep-based framework for simulation studies.

title: Research
text:
Electron-Ion Collider
Before joining Belle II, I worked on the development and implementation of advanced machine learning algorithms for energy and angle reconstruction in the Zero-Degree Calorimeter for the future Electron-Ion Collider. Data from simulations was used to perform the first angle reconstruction for hadronic showers in the far-forward calorimetry using a graph neural network. I also worked with the ePIC collaboration on refinement and validation of a new DD4hep-based framework for simulation studies.
